passages.text: Life can only be understood backwards; but it must be lived forwards.
passages.context: The fundamental asymmetry: meaning comes in retrospect, but we must act before we understand.

passages.text: Anxiety is the dizziness of freedom.
passages.context: Anxiety isn't about threats but about possibility. The vertigo of having to choose.

passages.text: The most common form of despair is not being who you are.
passages.context: Despair isn't circumstance — it's self-betrayal. Living as anyone other than yourself.

passages.text: What labels me, negates me.
passages.context: Every classification reduces. To name is to limit. The self exceeds all labels.

passages.text: Truth is subjectivity.
passages.context: Objective truth doesn't transform. Only truth appropriated inwardly, passionately, changes us.

passages.text: People demand freedom of speech as a compensation for the freedom of thought which they seldom use.
passages.context: We fight for rights we don't exercise. The freedom to think matters more than the freedom to speak.

passages.text: Face the facts of being what you are, for that is what changes what you are.
passages.context: Transformation begins with honest seeing. Accept what you are; acceptance enables becoming.

passages.text: The function of prayer is not to influence God, but rather to change the nature of the one who prays.
passages.context: Prayer's work is on the pray-er. It transforms the one praying, not the one prayed to.

passages.text: To dare is to lose one's footing momentarily. Not to dare is to lose oneself.
passages.context: Risk costs stability. Not risking costs everything. Between temporary imbalance and permanent loss.

passages.text: Boredom is the root of all evil — the despairing refusal to be oneself.
passages.context: Boredom isn't trivial — it's spiritual failure. The refusal to be yourself manifests as ennui.

passages.text: There are two ways to be fooled. One is to believe what isn't true; the other is to refuse to believe what is true.
passages.context: Two deceptions: false belief and stubborn denial. Both miss reality.

passages.text: The Bible is very easy to understand. But we Christians are a bunch of scheming swindlers. We pretend to be unable to understand it because we know very well that the minute we understand, we are obliged to act accordingly.
passages.context: We feign confusion to avoid obligation. Understanding demands response; ignorance permits inaction.

passages.text: The self is a relation that relates itself to itself.
passages.context: The self isn't a thing but a process — relating to itself. Spirit is self-relating.

passages.text: Love is all, it gives all, and it takes all.
passages.context: Love's totality: complete gift, complete demand. Nothing partial about real love.

passages.text: Once you label me you negate me.
passages.context: Categories kill. The living self cannot be captured in labels. Naming is reducing.

passages.text: Don't forget to love yourself.
passages.context: Self-love as duty, not selfishness. You cannot love others without loving yourself.

passages.text: A man who as a physical being is always turned toward the outside, thinking that his happiness lies outside him, finally turns inward and discovers that the source is within him.
passages.context: The journey from external to internal. What we seek outside was always within.

passages.text: The greatest hazard of all, losing one's self, can occur very quietly in the world, as if it were nothing at all. No other loss can occur so quietly; any other loss — an arm, a leg, five dollars, a wife, etc. — is sure to be noticed.
passages.context: You can lose your self without noticing. Every other loss is obvious; soul-loss is silent.

passages.text: Purity of heart is to will one thing.
passages.source: Purity of Heart Is to Will One Thing
passages.context: Divided will is impure. Purity isn't about content but about singularity of purpose.

passages.text: It is perfectly true, as philosophers say, that life must be understood backwards. But they forget the other proposition, that it must be lived forwards.
passages.context: Philosophy's limitation: it grasps retrospectively what must be enacted prospectively.
